Author: zack#6467
Content: voting suffers tragedy of the commons. it probably wouldn't be hard to control the majority of notaries within 2 rounds of voting.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: is uses a sortition method to select 13 of the 64 to sign any given round

Author: zack#6467
Content: it seems like if you control the majority of notaries, then you undo blocks?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: how?

Author: zack#6467
Content: or at least censor them?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: notaries only propose a notarization

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if and only if a node already has the identical data, does it have any effect

Author: zack#6467
Content: 13 of the 64 sign ever block root, and include it in bitcoin, right?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: not every one, about every 10

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it anchors to the notarized chain

Author: zack#6467
Content: if a node has identical data... what pool is thhis "node" from? is it one of the 64? what data is identical or not identical? what are we comparing the data against to see if it is identical?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a node can go from a non-notarized chain to the notarized, but not the other way around

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: blockhash of a height about 10 minutes ago

Author: zack#6467
Content: how does a node "go" form one chain to another?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: normal nakamoto consensus that is just slightly modified with the rule that one a height has a valid notarization, it wont be reorged

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the data is the blockchain itself

Author: mrlynch#5735
Content: there were some articles published in regards to this, from the debate with the gentleman from twitter and the notary collusion scenario

Author: zack#6467
Content: so the notarizers are just a checkpointing system, and they write the root hash into bitcoin

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: notaries propose a notarization that 10 blocks ago the hash was H. all nodes see this and if indeed 10 blocks ago the hash was H, that becomes the new notarized height

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: to bitcoin and also to KMD

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and assetchains write to KMD and to themselves

Author: zack#6467
Content: they write their root hash onto themselves. wasn't it already there?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, but the BTC txid that has the notarization is added to the notarized data

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and for assetchains the KMD txid

Author: zack#6467
Content: oh, that way you can look it up faster

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: http://notarystats.com/

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: shows the current status of notarizations for 50 or so chains

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and even if the hash was already locally here, it is needed onchain to know that it was properly notarized and convenient to lookup and prevent reorging past it

Author: zack#6467
Content: fully synced Amoveo is currently 1.2 gigabytes.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 100 or so notarizations per day dont increase chain size that much

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the giant benefit is that even chains with very low hash rate can be relied on to not have their blocks rewritten (After it is notarized)

Author: zack#6467
Content: Can you compare Komodo to Cosmos? it seems like you are doing something somewhat similar, right?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: isnt cosmos having a small number of block producers?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: even permissioned if i remember right

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we also add the cross chain merkle data onto the notarization data that enables the automated cross chain tx

Author: zack#6467
Content: their root chain, the one that cooresponds with komodo chain, is using some POS consensus

Author: zack#6467
Content: you write the merkel roots from one chain onto the other?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so that aspect is quite different than cosmos, but they have a multichain architecture

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the assetchain notarization sends up merkle root of merkle roots

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and komodod uses this information to create a MoMoM merkle root of merkle root of merkle roots and that is also added tothe notarization

Author: zack#6467
Content: How does Komodo compare with drivechain? Any idea why Paul Sztorc isn't using Komodo?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: paul probably has a bunch of preconceived ideas about komodo, dont know him personally so I am only guessing

Author: zack#6467
Content: Have you looked at drivechain though? it's an idea for bitcoin sidechains

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we are implementing a gateways based sidechains

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: deposit crypto and instead of just getting a token you get the native coin

Author: zack#6467
Content: deposit what crypto where? isn't every token native to something?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it isnt fully decentralized, but an automated multisig with the top notaries as signers is a pretty good distribution

Author: zack#6467
Content: what isn't decentralized?

Author: zack#6467
Content: what are you distributing?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: deposit KMD to the deposit multisig address for the sidechain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then automatically you can create coins on the destination chain

Author: zack#6467
Content: oh, komodo has some trick for moving KMD onto all the chains?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: only the withdraw requires the multisig signers to sign the multisig withraw

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but this method can move any bitcoin protocol coin

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: sidechain by federated multisig, i think they call it

Author: zack#6467
Content: you mean withdrawing KMD from an altcoin back onto Komodo requires the signatures of all the notaries?

Author: zack#6467
Content: the 13 for that round?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no, no

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you are combining things

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this is technically unrelated to notarizations

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: however we have community elected notaries

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: which by definition have a bit of trust

Author: zack#6467
Content: the notaries are just for checkpointing. so what is the trick to move KMD between the chains?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and the top ones in an automated multisig is a very practical federation

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: gateways CC

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: is for tokenizing

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: using a very similar process, instead of issuing tokens on deposit, the native coins for the side chain is issue

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it uses a variation of our burn/import protocol

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that one allows N different chains to form a fungible cluster

Author: zack#6467
Content: so, what if the notaries all go on strike at the same time?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so we have the ability to burn coins on one chain and import them on another, using the MoMoM

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then notarizations stop, but the blockchain will keep going

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: multisig deposits would be stuck

Author: zack#6467
Content: so it will make the low-hashpower chains less secure, and nothing more

Author: siu - Chainmakers#3920
Content: jeez, seems like i just extended this by 6 more hours just because i mentioned dpow 🤦

Author: zack#6467
Content: oh, and moving money between the chains freezes?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: low hashrate chains are less secure, yes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we are making a backup method to importcoins

Author: zack#6467
Content: komodo also has POW for issuing more KMD?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but that will still require signatures from a few notaries

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes PoW for the main KMD chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: assetchains can configure 0% to 100% PoS

Author: zack#6467
Content: what algorithm is the POW?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: equihash

Author: zack#6467
Content:
if there was an oracle on one of the assetchains, and the assetchain's POW forked the chain in 2, such that each side had a different oracle result, then all the KMD on that assetchain would get duplicated.
I guess the notaries would choose which side of the chain wins?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the import process relies on several rounds of notarizations

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it only issues new coins after things are already notarized and cant change

Author: zack#6467
Content: would the notaries choose which side of the chain wins?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i dont understand the scenario

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a height is either notarized or not

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if it is, then it wont change

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the notarized chain wins

Content:
`so, what if the notaries all go on strike at the same time?`

Author: zack#6467
Content: if one of the asset chains has a fork in it's POW, so there are 2 versions of it being mined, would the notaries have any influence over which version of the chain wins?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if the assetchain  is forked it is likely that the notaries will have a hard time coming to consensus

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we have seen during network events notarizations slowing down, this is an indication something is wrong

Author: zack#6467
Content: If I controlled more than half of the notaries, and I wanted one side of the chains fork to win, could I force it?
